annotation.spannedText: Minnesota's Somali community has seen an uptick in vaccine resistance due to fears of a link to autism

annotation.spannedText: that any side effects from vaccines are rare, and there is no evidence that vaccines cause autism

annotation.spannedText: "Usually, states will see one or two cases in a year, and what's concerning is, as of today, we'll be at 48 cases of measles,"

annotation.spannedText: "The most worrisome thing is, it's a completely unnecessary outbreak," ... "We have a vaccine that can prevent measles, and yet we're seeing this widespread transmission."

annotation.spannedText: That's when parents started to notice a disproportionate number of Somali children receiving special education services for autism in Minneapolis, which is in Hennepin County

classMention.mentionClass: That's when parents started to notice a disproportionate number of Somali children receiving special education services for autism in Minneapolis, which is in Hennepin County

annotation.spannedText: "At that point, the anti-vaccine groups just really started targeting the community,"

classMention.mentionClass: "At that point, the anti-vaccine groups just really started targeting the community,"

annotation.spannedText: "Between 2000 and roughly 2008, the Somali community in Minnesota actually had some of the highest vaccination rates for 2-year-olds of any population in the state,"

classMention.mentionClass: "Between 2000 and roughly 2008, the Somali community in Minnesota actually had some of the highest vaccination rates for 2-year-olds of any population in the state,"

annotation.spannedText: Michael Osterholm, regents professor and director of the Center for Infectious Disease Research and Policy at the University of Minnesota and a former state epidemiologist for Minnesota

classMention.mentionClass: Michael Osterholm, regents professor and director of the Center for Infectious Disease Research and Policy at the University of Minnesota and a former state epidemiologist for Minnesota

annotation.spannedText: As parents searched for answers as to why some Somali children were diagnosed with autism, they landed upon the work of discredited British researcher Andrew Wakefield, who first proposed a link between vaccines and autism in a paper later found to be fraudulent

classMention.mentionClass: As parents searched for answers as to why some Somali children were diagnosed with autism, they landed upon the work of discredited British researcher Andrew Wakefield, who first proposed a link between vaccines and autism in a paper later found to be fraudulent

annotation.spannedText: At the same time, local anti-vaccination activists started to hold meetings in the community

classMention.mentionClass: At the same time, local anti-vaccination activists started to hold meetings in the community

annotation.spannedText: "So, by about 2008, we started to see the vaccine rates drop as the word got through the Somali community that autism was linked to measles vaccination," ... "In the years since then, Andrew Wakefield has actually been brought in several times to the Somali community here in Minnesota to actually give presentations supporting this information. ... His work has been retracted."

classMention.mentionClass: "So, by about 2008, we started to see the vaccine rates drop as the word got through the Somali community that autism was linked to measles vaccination," ... annotation.spannedText: "Measles is a serious disease. You can have pneumonia and dehydration ... and people do die from measles, so we take it very seriously,"

annotation.spannedText: "Our goal for measles control is to protect all the individuals in the state, but for some people, they can't be vaccinated because of health conditions," ...
